body.p:
Frankfort Ky.
Jan 31st 1863,
To His Excellency, James F. Robinson, Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Whereas, it is known to us, the undersigned your petitioners, that the Subject of this memorial, who was confined in the penitentiary of the State of Kentucky on the 25th day of Oct. A. D. 1859, under sentence of court by judgment of conviction in Jefferson Cir. for the term of ten years, & for the crime of burglary, has up to this day served faithfully in execution of said sentence of conviction, and, at all times, without murmering or repining, but, with apparent cheeerful: and, though blind for fourteen years, without the possibility of recovery of his sight has never, to our knowledge, shirk from any duty; but in strict obedience to orders acting faithfully,

That your prisoner, Charles Sullivan,
being in no sense a pauper, but, of right in possession of ample means for a comfortable maintenance and that his family and friends in the City of Louisville being in circumstances of pecuniary independence; we, feel not onlly safe in asking his restoration to liberty, but, earnestly, and anxiously pray Your Excellency to grant in his behalf this Executive clemency

In asking the consideration of Your Excellency upon our petition, we feel that it is we ask pardon, if it shall seem incompatible with the publlic welfare to grant our prayer. But. we believe the object, one of mercy: which if granted, will confer an inestimable favor upon the poor blind prisoner: almost the only comfort left to
an afflicted sister who had, of physical comforts in plenty, but pines for the Society of the brother of her infancy

Considering these facts: viz. the invalidity of your prisoner, the evidence of the end of the judgment, and the favor it will confer upon an afflicted sister, to restore by the Executive pardon, one so needy and really worthy, we believe will be a subject of commendation by all good people, and a sense of gratification, at any rate to us your memorialists.
We therefore trusting to the native goodness of Your Excellency, shall feel safe with this representation to you and satisfied with its determination and may Heaven bless those named.

M. Eliza South
M E Taylor
M Luckett
Ben Luckett
Ann Luckett
R W Lawlace
L S Prentiss
J. T, Hockensmith
R W Wilhort
